column2: What do you say in these situations? Put the words in the correct order.
column3:
I use my car very little. There's no point in keeping it.
You say:
I {{c1::might}} {{c1::as}} {{c1::well}} {{c1::sell}} {{c1::it}} (sell / well / it / as / might).

column2: What do you say in these situations? Put the words in the correct order.
column3:
You're going out with a friend. It's early and you have plenty of time, but you're both ready to go. There's no point in waiting.
You say:
We {{c1::might}} {{c1::as}} {{c1::well}} {{c1::leave}} {{c1::now}} (now / as / might / leave / well).

column2: What do you say in these situations? Put the words in the correct order.
column3:
It's 6 a.m. and you've just woken up. You don't usually get up so early, but you feel good and the sun is shining.
You say to yourself:
I {{c1::might}} {{c1::as}} {{c1::well}} {{c1::get}} {{c1::up}} (up / well / might / as / get).

column2: What do you say in these situations? Put the words in the correct order.
column3:
Your TV is broken and it will cost a lot to repair.
You say:
I {{c1::might}} {{c1::as}} {{c1::well}} {{c1::buy}} {{c1::a}} {{c1::new}} {{c1::one}} (well / a / buy / one / as / might / new).

column2: What do you say in these situations? Put the words in the correct order.
column3:
You've just painted your kitchen. You still have a lot of paint, so why not use it for the bathroom?
You say:
We {{c1::might}} {{c1::as}} {{c1::well}} {{c1::paint}} {{c1::the}} {{c1::bathroom}} {{c1::too}} (bathroom / well / the / paint / too / as / might).
